Awarded to Soldiers who complete Ranger School; signifies elite small-unit leadership skills.
Awarded to Soldiers who graduate the SF Qualification Course; signifies Green Beret status.
Awarded to Soldiers who complete the Sapper Leader Course; represents combat engineer excellence.
Airborne slang for a Soldier without jump qualification.
Slang for a Soldier's first parachute jump in Airborne units.
Parachute jump where the chute is automatically deployed by a line attached to the aircraft.
Slang for a parachute jump performed without ruck or combat gear.
An airborne operation where Soldiers parachute into a combat zone; marked with a mustard stain.
The specific job or specialty a Soldier is trained and assigned in.
Movement of a Soldier and family to a new duty station.
Short-term assignment away from permanent duty station.
The official end date of a Soldier's service contract.
Monthly pay stub for Soldiers showing pay, allowances, and deductions.
Monthly allowance for housing when government quarters are not provided.
Monthly allowance to offset the cost of a Soldier's meals.
Term used to indicate the end of the duty day.
Low-cost group life insurance for Soldiers, administered by the VA.
System used to schedule and manage training ranges and facilities.

meaning: Army Training Requirements and Resources System
description: Online system for managing Army training seats and schools.
System used by units to track training, readiness, and qualifications.
System used for arranging and reimbursing official travel.
Logistics and supply chain management system for the Army.

meaning: Integrated Personnel and Pay System - Army
description: System for managing personnel and pay functions.
Term for an area with relative security and restricted access inside a combat or forward operating environment.
Term for an area with elevated threat levels where force protection measures are required.
Report term used when friendly forces are engaged with hostile forces and require immediate support.

meaning: Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty
description: Official form documenting a service member's service history and separation status.

meaning: Wear and Appearance of Army Uniforms and Insignia
description: Army regulation that prescribes the uniform standards and grooming rules for Soldiers.
Slang for rotary-wing aircraft commonly used for transport, medevac, or close air support.
Slang meaning a situation or plan that is completely disorganized or has failed badly.
Slang for a Soldier who avoids work or feigns injury/illness to dodge duties.
A homemade bomb or explosive used by irregular forces against personnel or vehicles.
An IED placed or concealed within a vehicle and used as a weapon against personnel or infrastructure.
Derogatory slang for a Soldier who rarely leaves the Forward Operating Base (FOB) and avoids outside missions.
A temporary task or duty assignment (example: police call, fireguard, chow detail) usually assigned to small groups.
Unit-wide time set aside for cleaning areas, picking up trash, and general maintenance; often performed on weekends or before inspections.
Abbreviation for the Department of the Army; used as a prefix in regulations, forms, and official references (DA).
Standardized Army forms (DA Form) used for personnel, administrative, and training actions (examples: DA Form 31, DA Form 4856).
Informal term for a commercial or unit field food vendor that pulls up to the base or range to sell meals and snacks.
Slang for over-the-counter pain relievers (commonly Motrin/ibuprofen) carried by Soldiers to treat aches and minor injuries.
Slang for a Soldier's bed or sleeping area in the barracks or field environment.
Field slang for a shelter, tent, or small living space used by Soldiers while deployed or in training.
Slang for the collection of ribbons, badges, and medals worn on the uniform chest; often used to describe a Soldier with many awards.
Slang for being subjected to arbitrary or petty punishment, policy, or bad luck imposed by the organization or leadership.
Soldier who directs vehicle movement (especially during loading/unloading or reversing) to prevent accidents and guide drivers safely.
A code that identifies specialized training, skills, or qualifications held by a soldier in addition to their MOS.
Military free-fall parachute system designed for special operations, providing greater maneuverability and load capacity.
The standard non-maneuverable static-line parachute used by U.S. Army airborne forces, designed to replace the T-10.
Formal military schooling required for officers to serve in joint duty assignments.
Mandatory briefing conducted before airborne operations covering parachute procedures, malfunctions, and safety protocols.
Slang for a medical professional, usually at sick call or MEPS, who draws blood for testing.
Federal status. DoD authority under federal control for active duty missions.
National Guard under state control with federal pay for training or ops.
Governor-ordered duty under state law. State funded.
Sensitive but unclassified information requiring safeguarding.
Personnel, admin, and manpower policy.
All-source intelligence support to the commander.
Current operations, execution, and battle rhythm.
Sustainment, distribution, maintenance, and health services.
Operational plans and strategy development.
Communications, networks, and cyber integration.
Annual law authorizing DoD programs and policies.
Logical line linking tasks to an objective.
Light utility helicopter used for support and training.
Location description indicating nearby proximity.
Purpose statement linking tasks to effects.
Combatant command for Europe and parts of Eurasia.
Combatant command for Africa (except Egypt).
Combatant command for homeland defense and support.
Combatant command for Latin America and the Caribbean.
Designated person for coordination or information.
Command element of a unit or organization.
Small concealed site for listening and observing.
Published unit procedure for routine tasks.
Rate of operations or activities over time.
Chargeable time off from duty.
Nickname for the 1st Armored Division, honoring the Navy's USS Constitution.
Nickname for the 4th Infantry Division, from the Roman numeral IV and its ivy patch.
Nickname for the 25th Infantry Division, referencing its Pacific service.

NATO phonetic alphabet letter for 'Z'. Used in radio communications to clearly distinguish letters, especially in noisy or unclear transmission conditions. Also commonly used to denote UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) in military time references.

Radio proword indicating that the last transmission has been received and understood. Does NOT mean agreement or compliance, only acknowledgment of receipt. Commonly misused in civilian contexts to mean 'yes' or 'agreed'.

Radio proword indicating that the message has been received, understood, and will be complied with. WILCO includes the meaning of ROGER, so both terms should not be used together. Used to acknowledge orders or instructions that will be executed.

Radio proword indicating that the transmission is ended and no response is required or expected. Always the last word spoken in a radio transmission. Never use 'OVER AND OUT' - this is incorrect; transmissions end with either OVER (expecting reply) or OUT (no reply expected).

Radio proword indicating that the transmission is ended and a response is expected. Used at the end of a transmission when you are passing the conversation to the other station. Never combined with OUT.

Radio proword used to indicate the separation between portions of a message or between multiple messages being transmitted in sequence. Not to be confused with BREAK BREAK, which indicates an urgent interruption.

Radio proword used to interrupt an ongoing transmission when there is an urgent or emergency message that takes priority. All stations must cease transmitting immediately when BREAK BREAK is called. Different from a single BREAK, which is non-urgent message separation.

Radio proword used to request a repeat of a previous transmission or portion thereof. Never use the word 'repeat' on radio, as REPEAT is a fire support term meaning to fire the same mission again. Can specify what portion to repeat (e.g., 'Say again all after checkpoint').

Radio proword indicating that the following word or phrase will be spelled out using the phonetic alphabet. Used to ensure clarity for unusual words, proper names, grid coordinates, or critical information that must be transmitted accurately.

Radio proword used to request verification that the transmitting station is authorized and genuine. The challenged station must respond with the correct authentication code from the Signal Operating Instructions (SOI). Used to prevent enemy forces from impersonating friendly stations.

Radio proword meaning the transmitting station must pause for a few seconds before continuing. If the delay will be longer than a few seconds, use WAIT OUT. The receiving station should not transmit during a WAIT unless there is an emergency.

Radio proword meaning the transmitting station must pause for longer than a few seconds and will call back when ready. The receiving station is released from monitoring and can perform other tasks until called. Different from WAIT, which implies a short pause.
Radio proword indicating that the receiving station is ready to receive a transmission. Used in response to a station calling with traffic or when acknowledging readiness to copy a message.

Radio proword used to request a signal strength and clarity report from another station. Response format is 'LOUD AND CLEAR' (best), 'WEAK BUT READABLE', 'WEAK AND DISTORTED', etc. Used to verify radio communications are functioning properly.

Radio proword indicating that the frequency is not being used and is available for transmission. Also used by radio operators when finishing operations on a specific frequency to indicate they are leaving the net.

Radio proword used to indicate an error was made in the transmission and the correct version will follow. The corrected information is spoken after saying CORRECTION. Helps maintain clarity and accuracy in radio communications.

meaning: Private (Army/Marines), Airman Basic (Air Force), Seaman Recruit (Navy)
description: Lowest enlisted rank across all military branches. Entry-level personnel in initial training or first duty assignment. No leadership responsibilities. Pay grade E-1.

meaning: Private First Class (Army), Lance Corporal (Marines), Airman First Class (Air Force), Seaman (Navy)
description: Third enlisted rank. Demonstrates competency in basic military tasks and specialty training. May supervise junior personnel. Eligible for certain specialized training. Pay grade E-3.

meaning: Specialist/Corporal (Army), Corporal (Marines), Senior Airman (Air Force), Petty Officer Third Class (Navy)
description: Fourth enlisted rank and first non-commissioned officer rank in some branches. Experienced in specialty and capable of supervising small teams. Army E-4s can be either Specialist (no leadership authority) or Corporal (NCO with leadership authority). Pay grade E-4.

meaning: Sergeant (Army/Marines), Staff Sergeant (Air Force), Petty Officer Second Class (Navy)
description: Fifth enlisted rank and key non-commissioned officer level. First-line supervisors with direct responsibility for junior enlisted. Typically leads teams or crews. Expected to mentor and train subordinates. Pay grade E-5.

meaning: Staff Sergeant (Army/Marines), Technical Sergeant (Air Force), Petty Officer First Class (Navy)
description: Sixth enlisted rank. Experienced NCO responsible for managing sections or multiple teams. Serves as primary advisor to junior officers. Highly skilled in specialty area with significant leadership responsibilities. Pay grade E-6.

meaning: Sergeant First Class (Army), Gunnery Sergeant (Marines), Master Sergeant (Air Force), Chief Petty Officer (Navy)
description: Seventh enlisted rank and senior non-commissioned officer. Manages operations at platoon level or equivalent. Extensive experience and expertise in specialty. Key advisor to commanders on enlisted matters. Pay grade E-7.

meaning: Master Sergeant/First Sergeant (Army), Master Sergeant/First Sergeant (Marines), Senior Master Sergeant (Air Force), Senior Chief Petty Officer (Navy)
description: Eighth enlisted rank. Senior leadership position managing company-level or equivalent operations. First Sergeants serve as principal NCO advisor to company commanders. Master Sergeants operate in technical specialist roles. Pay grade E-8.

meaning: Sergeant Major/Command Sergeant Major (Army), Sergeant Major/Master Gunnery Sergeant (Marines), Chief Master Sergeant (Air Force), Master Chief Petty Officer (Navy)
description: Highest enlisted rank. Senior enlisted advisor to battalion-level or higher commanders. Represents enlisted force on policy and welfare matters. Command Sergeant Majors/Sergeants Major serve in command positions while Master Gunnery Sergeants/Chief Master Sergeants serve as technical experts. Pay grade E-9.

Lowest commissioned officer rank. Entry-level officer, typically recent commissioning source graduate (ROTC, Academy, OCS). Learning leadership and management while leading small units such as platoons. Pay grade O-1.

meaning: First Lieutenant (Army/Marines/Air Force), Lieutenant Junior Grade (Navy/Coast Guard)
description: Second commissioned officer rank. Experienced platoon leader or staff officer. Developing leadership skills and tactical proficiency. Typically serving in operational assignments. Pay grade O-2.

Third commissioned officer rank. Commands company-sized units (100-200 soldiers) or serves as primary staff officer. Expected to be technically and tactically proficient. Key leadership position in most units. Pay grade O-3.

Fourth commissioned officer rank. Battalion/squadron staff officer or executive officer. Experienced operational leader serving as principal staff officers or deputy commanders. Bridge between company-grade and field-grade officers. Pay grade O-4.

Fifth commissioned officer rank. Commands battalion-sized units (300-1,000 soldiers) or serves as senior staff officer. Expected to provide operational and strategic guidance. Senior field grade officer. Pay grade O-5.

Sixth commissioned officer rank. Commands brigade-sized units (3,000-5,000 soldiers) or large installations. Senior leadership position with significant operational responsibility. Highest field grade rank before general officer. Pay grade O-6.

meaning: Brigadier General (Army/Marines/Air Force), Rear Admiral Lower Half (Navy/Coast Guard)
description: Seventh commissioned officer rank and first general/flag officer rank. Commands division-sized units or serves as deputy commander of large organizations. Requires Senate confirmation. General officer responsible for strategic planning and operations. Pay grade O-7.

meaning: Major General (Army/Marines/Air Force), Rear Admiral Upper Half (Navy/Coast Guard)
description: Eighth commissioned officer rank. Commands division-sized units (10,000-15,000 soldiers) or serves as senior staff officer at major commands. Strategic leader responsible for large-scale operations and policy. Pay grade O-8.

meaning: Lieutenant General (Army/Marines/Air Force), Vice Admiral (Navy/Coast Guard)
description: Ninth commissioned officer rank. Commands corps-sized units (20,000-45,000 soldiers) or serves as deputy commander of major commands. Senior general officer responsible for theater-level operations and strategic planning. Pay grade O-9.

Tenth and highest commissioned officer rank in peacetime. Commands major commands, serves as Joint Chiefs of Staff, or leads combatant commands. Highest strategic leadership position. Five-star ranks (O-11) exist only in wartime. Pay grade O-10.

Army MOS responsible for analyzing intelligence information from multiple sources to assess enemy capabilities, vulnerabilities, and probable courses of action. Produces intelligence reports, briefings, and assessments to support commanders' decision-making. Works with SIGINT, HUMINT, IMINT, and other intelligence disciplines.

Army MOS responsible for analyzing and interpreting imagery from various sources including satellites, aircraft, and drones. Produces geospatial intelligence products such as maps, charts, and terrain analysis to support military operations. Identifies enemy positions, facilities, and activities through imagery analysis.

Army MOS responsible for conducting counterintelligence operations to detect, identify, assess, and counter threats from foreign intelligence services, terrorists, and insider threats. Conducts investigations, interviews, and surveillance. Protects personnel, facilities, and classified information from espionage and sabotage.

Army MOS responsible for conducting human intelligence (HUMINT) collection operations through interrogations, debriefings, and source operations. Interviews detainees, refugees, and other sources to gather critical information about enemy forces, intentions, and capabilities. Requires advanced language and cultural skills.

Army MOS responsible for analyzing intercepted foreign communications and electronic signals to identify, locate, and report on enemy activities. Operates sophisticated electronic equipment to collect and process signals intelligence (SIGINT). Provides critical intelligence on enemy communications networks and electronic warfare capabilities.

Army MOS responsible for identifying, categorizing, translating, and analyzing foreign language communications collected through signals intelligence. Operates voice intercept equipment and provides real-time translation of intercepted communications. Requires proficiency in a foreign language and Top Secret/SCI clearance.

Army MOS responsible for collecting and analyzing electronic signals and communications. Operates signals intelligence collection equipment, identifies foreign signals, and provides technical analysis of intercepted data. Supports tactical and strategic intelligence operations with real-time SIGINT reporting.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining, repairing, and installing intelligence electronic equipment and systems. Ensures all intelligence collection and analysis equipment is operational. Integrates various intelligence systems and troubleshoots technical problems in deployed environments.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining, processing, and troubleshooting information systems, networks, and equipment. Installs and configures hardware and software, provides technical support, and maintains network security. Critical for ensuring all military IT infrastructure remains operational.

Army MOS responsible for operating and performing unit-level maintenance on radio communication equipment. Installs, operates, and maintains tactical radio systems including vehicle-mounted and manpack radios. Ensures reliable voice and data communications in field environments.

Army MOS responsible for installing, maintaining, and repairing cable and wire communication systems. Installs fiber optic and copper cable systems, troubleshoots connectivity issues, and maintains telecommunications infrastructure. Essential for establishing fixed communication networks at bases and command posts.

Army MOS responsible for operating and maintaining tactical network equipment including routers, switches, and communication nodes. Establishes and maintains data networks that connect command posts and forward operating bases. Critical for enabling military network communications in deployed environments.

Army MOS responsible for installing, operating, and maintaining multichannel satellite and line-of-sight communication systems. Operates tropospheric scatter, microwave, and satellite terminals to provide long-distance voice and data communications. Enables strategic and tactical communications across large distances.

Army MOS responsible for installing, operating, and maintaining satellite communication terminals and systems. Establishes satellite links for voice, data, and video communications. Provides beyond-line-of-sight communications capability essential for command and control in remote or deployed locations.

Army MOS responsible for installing, maintaining, and troubleshooting signal support systems and terminal devices. Jack-of-all-trades signal soldier who can operate radios, maintain computers, and troubleshoot communication equipment. Most common signal MOS with broad technical skills across multiple communication systems.

Army MOS responsible for inspecting, maintaining, repairing, and modifying biomedical equipment used in military medical facilities. Works on devices such as patient monitors, ventilators, defibrillators, and diagnostic equipment. Ensures all medical equipment meets safety standards and remains operational for patient care.

Army MOS responsible for providing nursing care to patients in military medical facilities and field environments. Administers medications, performs basic nursing procedures, assists physicians, and monitors patient conditions. Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) qualified to provide bedside nursing care under supervision of physicians or registered nurses.

Army MOS responsible for assisting surgeons and anesthesiologists during surgical procedures. Prepares operating rooms, sterilizes instruments, maintains aseptic technique, and assists during operations. Trained in surgical technology including proper handling of instruments, suturing techniques, and patient positioning.

Army MOS responsible for providing dental care support including dental hygiene, preventive dentistry, and assisting dentists during procedures. Performs dental cleanings, takes x-rays, prepares dental materials, and maintains dental equipment. Provides field dental support during deployments.

Army MOS responsible for assisting physical therapists in treating patients with injuries, disabilities, or movement disorders. Administers therapeutic exercises, modalities, and treatments under supervision. Helps soldiers recover from injuries and return to duty through rehabilitation programs.

Army MOS responsible for managing patient administration duties in military medical facilities. Processes admissions, discharges, transfers, maintains medical records, and coordinates patient appointments. Ensures proper documentation and administrative support for medical operations.

Army MOS responsible for fabricating, fitting, and dispensing eyeglasses and contact lenses. Operates optical laboratory equipment, performs vision screenings, and ensures proper fit of corrective eyewear. Maintains optical equipment and provides vision care support for military personnel.

Army MOS responsible for managing medical supplies, equipment, and pharmaceuticals. Orders, receives, stores, and distributes medical materiel to support medical operations. Maintains inventory control systems and ensures proper storage and handling of medical supplies including controlled substances.

Army MOS responsible for performing clinical laboratory tests to assist in diagnosing and treating diseases. Conducts blood tests, urinalysis, microbiology cultures, and other laboratory procedures. Operates and maintains laboratory equipment in both fixed facilities and field environments.

Army MOS responsible for operating X-ray and radiological equipment to produce diagnostic images. Performs radiographic procedures, processes images, and maintains radiation safety protocols. Provides critical diagnostic imaging support in both garrison and deployed medical facilities.

Army MOS responsible for preparing and dispensing medications under supervision of pharmacists. Maintains pharmacy inventory, compounds medications, and provides patient education on proper medication use. Ensures safe storage and distribution of pharmaceuticals including controlled substances.

Army MOS responsible for inspecting food products and food service facilities to ensure safety and compliance with standards. Assists veterinarians with animal care, conducts food safety inspections, and monitors food storage and preparation. Prevents foodborne illness in military dining facilities.

Army MOS responsible for preventing disease and injury through environmental health surveillance and analysis. Conducts inspections of food, water, and sanitation facilities. Monitors disease vectors, pest control, and occupational health hazards. Critical for maintaining force health protection in deployed environments.

Army MOS responsible for providing veterinary care for military working dogs and other animals. Assists veterinarians with examinations, treatments, and surgeries. Maintains animal health records and ensures proper care, feeding, and housing of military animals. Critical for maintaining operational capability of military working dog teams.

Army MOS responsible for administering respiratory therapy treatments to patients with breathing disorders. Operates ventilators and respiratory equipment, performs pulmonary function tests, and provides emergency airway management. Critical for treating combat casualties with respiratory injuries and managing critically ill patients.

Army MOS responsible for providing emergency medical treatment, limited primary care, and health protection on the battlefield and in garrison. Trained in tactical combat casualty care (TCCC), trauma management, and field medicine. The backbone of Army medical care, often the first medical responder for wounded soldiers.

Army MOS responsible for assisting with mental health treatment and counseling services. Conducts intake screenings, assists with therapy sessions, maintains behavioral health records, and provides support for soldiers with mental health conditions. Critical for addressing PTSD, depression, anxiety, and other behavioral health issues.

Army MOS responsible for conducting sensitive criminal investigations including felonies, fraud, corruption, and serious incidents. Warrant officer position requiring extensive law enforcement experience. Operates independently to investigate serious crimes affecting Army personnel and interests. Similar to civilian federal agents.

Army MOS responsible for supervising and managing detention facilities and detainee operations. Provides security, custody, and control of detainees. Conducts searches, maintains records, and ensures compliance with Geneva Convention standards. Operates Enemy Prisoner of War (EPW) and civilian internee facilities.

Army MOS responsible for training, handling, and caring for military working dogs used in detection, patrol, and specialized missions. Conducts explosives and narcotics detection operations, provides security, and maintains dog health and welfare. Dogs and handlers form highly trained teams for combat and law enforcement operations.

Army MOS responsible for supervising and performing duties related to water terminal, rail, and cargo operations. Loads and unloads cargo, operates material handling equipment, and coordinates movement of supplies and equipment. Critical for logistics and supply chain operations in deployed environments.

Army MOS responsible for operating and navigating Army watercraft including utility boats, landing craft, and tugboats. Performs deck operations, maintains watercraft systems, and conducts over-water transportation missions. Provides critical capability for amphibious operations and river crossings.

Army MOS responsible for operating and maintaining propulsion systems, electrical systems, and auxiliary equipment on Army watercraft. Performs maintenance and repairs on marine engines, generators, pumps, and other mechanical systems. Ensures watercraft remain mission-capable for transportation operations.

Army MOS responsible for operating trucks, buses, and other wheeled vehicles to transport personnel, supplies, and equipment. Performs operator-level maintenance, conducts convoy operations, and ensures safe transportation in all environments. Most common transportation MOS and critical for logistics operations.

Army MOS responsible for coordinating and managing movement of personnel and equipment via all transportation modes. Plans convoy routes, prepares transportation documentation, and tracks cargo movements. Uses automated systems to schedule and coordinate complex multi-modal transportation operations.

Army MOS responsible for inspecting, maintaining, and repairing railway cars, locomotives, and associated equipment. Performs mechanical repairs on rail systems, conducts safety inspections, and ensures rail equipment is mission-ready. Supports military rail operations and strategic deployment capabilities.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing railway track, roadbed, and related structures. Operates track maintenance equipment, replaces rails and ties, and ensures track safety standards. Supports military rail transportation infrastructure and rapid deployment capabilities.

Army MOS responsible for operating and managing military railway operations. Operates locomotives, conducts switching operations, and coordinates train movements. Supports strategic deployment and logistics operations via military and commercial rail networks.

Army MOS responsible for supervising and performing maintenance on aircraft turbine engines and associated systems. Troubleshoots engine problems, performs inspections, and conducts test runs. Critical for maintaining aviation fleet readiness and ensuring safe flight operations.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing helicopter transmissions, drive systems, and rotor systems. Performs component-level maintenance on gearboxes, drive shafts, and rotor assemblies. Essential for maintaining helicopter fleet operational readiness.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing unmanned aircraft systems (UAS/drones) including airframes, payloads, and ground control stations. Troubleshoots electronic and mechanical systems, performs pre-flight inspections, and ensures UAS mission readiness. Critical for supporting reconnaissance and surveillance operations.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing aircraft electrical systems including generators, batteries, wiring, and lighting. Troubleshoots electrical problems, performs continuity checks, and ensures all electrical systems meet safety standards. Essential for aircraft operational readiness.

Army MOS responsible for repairing aircraft structural components including metal and composite airframes, control surfaces, and landing gear. Performs sheet metal work, welding, composite repairs, and structural modifications. Critical for maintaining aircraft structural integrity and flight safety.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing aircraft pneumatic and hydraulic systems including flight controls, landing gear, and braking systems. Troubleshoots hydraulic leaks, services systems, and replaces components. Essential for aircraft controllability and safety.

Army MOS responsible for coordinating aviation missions, maintaining flight operations records, and providing administrative support for aviation units. Prepares mission briefings, tracks aircraft status, processes flight plans, and maintains operations security. Critical for safe and efficient aviation operations.

Army MOS responsible for directing aircraft takeoffs, landings, and ground movements. Operates radar and communication equipment to provide separation between aircraft and ensure flight safety. Manages airfield operations and coordinates with military and civilian air traffic control agencies. Critical for preventing mid-air collisions and ensuring safe flight operations.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing AH-64 Apache attack helicopters. Performs inspections, troubleshooting, and repairs on airframe, engines, weapons systems, and avionics specific to Apache helicopters. Specialized maintenance for Army's premier attack helicopter platform.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters. Performs inspections, troubleshooting, and repairs on all Black Hawk systems including airframe, engines, transmissions, and avionics. Most common aviation maintenance MOS focused on Army's primary utility helicopter.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing CH-47 Chinook helicopters. Performs inspections, troubleshooting, and repairs on all Chinook systems including dual-rotor system, engines, transmissions, and avionics. Specialized maintenance for Army's heavy-lift cargo helicopter.

Army MOS responsible for operating unmanned aircraft systems (UAS/drones) for reconnaissance, surveillance, and target acquisition. Pilots drones remotely, analyzes real-time imagery, and coordinates with ground forces. Operates systems like Shadow, Gray Eagle, and other tactical UAS platforms. Critical for providing commanders with aerial intelligence.

Army MOS responsible for maintaining and repairing weapons systems, electrical systems, and avionics on AH-64D Apache helicopters. Troubleshoots and repairs fire control systems, missile systems, gun systems, and advanced electronics. Highly technical specialty maintaining Apache's combat systems.
